posts.title: Should I do a Master’s?
posts.title_plain: Should I do a Master’s?
posts.content:
Considering further study when you graduate?

Whether you are looking for further study to enable you to stand out from the crowd in the competitive job market or want to pursue a career in academia, this event will introduce you to the options available for postgraduate study at Portsmouth.

Over refreshments, visit the Information Fair to speak with course tutors, recruitment teams and current Master’s students about our specific courses. This will be followed by a presentation covering postgraduate study and your career, including what to expect academically and financially when studying at postgraduate level.

All students are welcome, regardless of department, course or year.

As a graduate of the University you may be eligible for the Alumni Scholarship, a 20 per cent discount on postgraduate course fees. Conditions apply.
posts.excerpt: Considering further study when you graduate? Whether you are looking for further study to enable you to stand out from the crowd in the competitive job market or want to pursue a career…

posts.title: Transmedia storytelling with Simon Wilkinson
posts.title_plain: Transmedia storytelling with Simon Wilkinson
posts.content:
The CCI PGRS Cohort are delighted to welcome Simon Wilkinson to the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries to deliver a lecture and workshop on transmedia storytelling, using a live project as a case study.

Simon Wilkinson is a British transmedia artist. His work incorporates audiovisual, installation, Virtual Reality, electronic music, and online and performance media, often combining all of these forms simultaneously. Wilkinson describes transmedia as ‘the practice of telling a story through multiple platforms; so that, for example, instead of making a website ‘about’ the theatre piece, the website becomes an embedded part of the narrative.’

He often uses transmedia platforms in order ‘to disrupt consensus reality and immerse audiences in experiences which blur the line between truth and fiction.’

Wilkinson, who currently produces work as Circa 69, has featured in Tate Modern’s Merge Festival (2011) and at many international festivals.

Simon has been described as “one of the most notable names in Europe to be dealing with VR” by Cineuropa Magazine. To find out more about his work, click here.

Simon guest lectures at a large number of international universities including Netherlands Film Academy, Sarajevo Academy of Fine Art, Bilkent University Ankara, Lima University of Technology and Engineering London College of Communication and a number of UK universities. He was the lead facilitator on British Council’s Transmedia Thinktank in Venezuela 2016 and in 2017 was a resident at Cambridge University’s Centre for the Future of Intelligence exploring the use of artificial intelligence in his practice.

Click here to register via Eventbrite and see the schedule.
posts.excerpt: The CCI PGRS Cohort are delighted to welcome Simon Wilkinson to the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries to deliver a lecture and workshop on transmedia storytelling, using a live project as a case study….

posts.title: WAPSN Workshop 2017: Tackling Security Challenges in West Africa
posts.title_plain: WAPSN Workshop 2017: Tackling Security Challenges in West Africa
posts.content:
The West African Peace and Security Network is pleased to confirm the details of its 2017 workshop to be held at University of Portsmouth between 29 and 30 June.

On the 29 June three expert panels will discuss the topics of maritime security in the Gulf of Guinea, donor responses to insecurity in West Africa and the rise of Boko Haram. The 30 June will involve a PhD workshop showcasing the latest research from postgraduate researchers working in the fields of maritime security in the Gulf of Guinea and jihad in the West African setting.

Both events will be held at the University of Portsmouth’s Portland Building (room 1.67). All are welcome but please RSVP in advance to marcus.mccorkell@port.ac.uk as space is limited.

posts.title: The Future of Cinematic Digital Cinematography – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.title_plain: The Future of Cinematic Digital Cinematography – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.content:
This Portsmouth Festivities lecture from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries features Daniel Mulligan of the School of Creative Technologies, where he will discuss new sensor technology and his research in this area alongside the latest techniques in Hollywood Film Productions and his experiences on films such as Captain Philips, Man from UNCLE, and much more.

“The area of Digital Cinematography for Feature Production is a new and constantly evolving environment. Our new Cine Imaging Lab based at the University of Portsmouth is developing new and interesting ways in which to capture and process Cinematic Images for the future of Production. Having worked on films such as Captain Philips and Jupiter Ascending, 1D3D and Tarzan, we can demonstrate and discuss the following subject areas”

  • Feature Film Location practices for the capture and distribution of high end content
  • Digital Cinema Lab system
  • New sensor technologies
  • New processing technologies
  • Cinematic Digital Cinematography and Colour Grading/Science.
  • New sensor technology and our research in this area.
  • Latest techniques in Hollywood Film Productions and my experiences on working with these films

£6.00/£4.50 concessions, book your tickets here

Room EW 1.10
posts.excerpt: This Portsmouth Festivities lecture from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries features Daniel Mulligan of the School of Creative Technologies, where he will discuss new sensor technology and his research in this area alongside…

posts.title: ‘The Oarsman’: Modulars and New Technologies – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.title_plain: ‘The Oarsman’: Modulars and New Technologies – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.content:
This Portsmouth Festivities lecture from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries features:

Following on from his successful 2016 Portsmouth Festival Modular synthesiser concert, Dr Pere Villez presents The Oarsman, a lecture/concert exploring the possibilities offered by combining old and new music technologies with phoneography.

“An exquisite Fusion of Vintage Electronic Music Tech and Drone Cinema. Past and present sound worlds collide to form mesmerising backdrops to a cinematic visual wilderness set in a nearby future where much of the Earth is under water. Ancient Thermionic Valve tech and digital sound sparks combine into a hypnotic climate omen told by an ancient oarsman!”

£6.00/£4.50 concessions, book tickets here

posts.title: Portsmouth Festivities Speakers Day
posts.title_plain: Portsmouth Festivities Speakers Day
posts.content:
This year’s Portsmouth Festivities Speakers Day (part of Portsmouth Festivities 16-25 June), brings together some of the UK’s most interesting speakers for you to meet and question.

  • Ken Livingstone, former Mayor of London, reports on the left’s possibilities and limitations, with reflections on the current state of the Labour Party.
  • Former Minister of Europe Denis MacShane discusses with the renowned Daily Mail writer: Peter Hitchens the issues surrounding Brexit.
  • Diane Darke reflects on her experiences and struggles with the realities of life on the ground inside Syria and the story of the house she bought.
  • Adrian Tinniswood, an English writer and historian who will be discussing his book the Long Weekend: Life in the English Country House Between the Wars, drawing on hundreds of memoirs on unpublished letters and diaries on the eye witness testimonies and intrigues of the life in the UK’s stately homes.
  • Andrew Lownie tells the tale of ‘Stalins Englishman’: the story of the double agent and spy Guy Burgess. The book won Guardian Book of the Year.
  • Dermot Turing, nephew of Alan Turing, takes a fresh look of the real stories behind the iconic codebreaker’s life and his cracking of the Enigma code.
  • Peter Clark, the well-known writer and Arabist, tells the story of a walk undertaken by  Charles Dickens and how walking features in Dickens’ stories.

Tickets are now available at www.portsmouthfestivities.co.uk/events/ or from the booking line: 023 9282 8282. Tickets cost £10.50 if booked by 22 May or after this date – £13.50 for single speaker and £47 for an all-inclusive day ticket.

eventvenue: St George's Church, St George's Square, Portsmouth

posts.title: Portsmouth Business School Postgraduate Open Evening
posts.title_plain: Portsmouth Business School Postgraduate Open Evening
posts.content:
We hold regular open evenings at Portsmouth Business School for those interested in our part-time undergraduate degrees, full and part-time postgraduate courses, and research degrees. These events provide an opportunity for you to meet lecturers, current and past students and people such as yourself, who are considering the benefits of studying at one of the South’s best business schools.

Our Student Finance team will be on hand to provide you with information about how to fund your studies, student loans, alumni discounts and scholarships.

Schedule:

5:00pm – Registration, refreshments, course information stands
5:30pm – Welcome by Jill Brown, Head of Postgraduate Programmes at Portsmouth Business School
5:45pm – Guest speaker, Fred Jones, Head of Cities (UK and Ireland) at Uber, whose presentation on ‘Uber’s vision of the Future of Urban Mobility’ will explain how new technology can allow us to use private cars for public good to reduce congestion, air pollution and land wasted on parking.
6:15pm – Drinks and canapés with teaching staff and current students
7:00pm – Finish

Parking is available after 5pm at a fixed charge of £2. Please see our map and directions page for more details.

Please check that the course you are interested in is offered by Portsmouth Business School rather than one of the other four faculties which make up the University before you decide to come along to our open evening. If it isn’t then we would recommend you attend one of the University-wide Postgraduate Information Days.

For further information, please contact us on bsro@port.ac.uk.
posts.excerpt: We hold regular open evenings at Portsmouth Business School for those interested in our part-time undergraduate degrees, full and part-time postgraduate courses, and research degrees. These events provide an opportunity for you to…

posts.title: Portsmouth at Play – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.title_plain: Portsmouth at Play – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.content:
This Portsmouth Festivities lecture from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries features the research of Senior Lecturer in Illustration Louis Netter, and will explore the decadent, seedy, and dangerous past of Portsmouth’s dockyard and surrounding areas, exploring this history through visual re-enactment in the form of drawings.

This colourful past was most vividly memorialised in Rowlandson’s image ‘Portsmouth Point’. This is one of the most recognisable images of Portsmouth and speaks to the cities long history of drunken debauchery and prostitution that plagued it for over 300 years. Other compelling factors combined to make this city a fascinating patchwork of urban renewal, social stratification and shifting identity.

This talk aims to be an immersive and imaginative exploration of history utilising a creative non-fiction approach through a fictional eyewitness. Those interested in Portsmouth history and drawing are encouraged to attend.

£6.00/£4.50 concessions, book your ticket here

Room EW 1.10
posts.excerpt: This Portsmouth Festivities lecture from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries features the research of Senior Lecturer in Illustration Louis Netter, and will explore the decadent, seedy, and dangerous past of Portsmouth’s dockyard…

posts.title: Playpower: the 60s counter-culture and the Summer of Love
posts.title_plain: Playpower: the 60s counter-culture and the Summer of Love
posts.content:
As part of a series of events celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Summer of Love, Portsmouth Guildhall will host Playpower: the 60s counter-culture and the Summer of Love this June.
The evening marks the 50th anniversary of the Monterey Pop Festival and Summer of Love, and will include performances from Bruce Barthol and Scarlet Town, a book launch of Autumn of Love by Dave Allen, the launch of Portsmouth’s Psychedelic Summers exhibition inside Portsmouth Music Experience, and extracts from a 1960s documentary by Nigel Grundy.

All welcome, free entry.

The event marks the Tuesday immediately following the 50th anniversary of the legendary Monterey Pop Festival, with notable performers such as Hendrix, Joplin, Who, Otis R, Shankar – and Bruce Barthol with Country Joe & the Fish.

Dave Allen will also be doing a Q&A with Bruce about the San Francisco Summer of Love and the Festival.

The film documentary focuses on interviews with local people from the time and the popular music scene in Portsmouth, from the arrival of rock & roll in 1956 through the 1960s and ending with early 1970s events.

In addition, the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries will be exhibiting student work inspired by the Summer of Love in the Freda Swain Room. (Interested in submitting? Check out the link here for details.) From September, the space will host an exhibition about the Summer of Love and 1967.

Dave says that he’s excited to be taking part in the events, and that working with the University of Portsmouth, Eldon Building and the city’s Art College history is key.

‘The Summer of Love and counterculture has been heavily documented almost exclusively in terms of San Francisco and London,” he explains. “The idea that nothing happens in provinces is simply not true.’

Dave discusses the importance of Portsmouth and the time period to him in anticipation of the launch of Autumn of Love, published by Moyhill, which will take place in the Harlequin Room at the start of the evening.

‘The Summer of Love has gone,’ he explains. ‘But I don’t think it ever died. Some of the ideas and practises are as powerful now as they ever were, but we have a much more mature view of what it’s all about – and that’s much more than rock and roll.’

Dave explains that although many suggest the movement inspired by the Summer of Love collapsed by the early 70’s, the changes and attitudes that people encountered, including new ideas such as the ecology movement and alternate approaches to spirituality, are still having an effect today.

‘Ultimately,’ concludes Dave. ‘I want to say that it never finished.’
posts.excerpt: As part of a series of events celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Summer of Love, Portsmouth Guildhall will host Playpower: the 60s counter-culture and the Summer of Love this June. The evening…

posts.title: Cry Baby – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.title_plain: Cry Baby – Portsmouth Festivities CCI Lectures
posts.content:
It’s a child’s toy. It’s the only instrument through which you breathe. It has the power of a locomotive yet sleeps in your pocket and cries like a baby.

Ben Hodgeson takes you on a journey of Blues Harmonica, from Germany to Liverpool via the Southern States, discovering some of the greatest players in history.This Portsmouth Festivities lecture from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries features:

● A race through harmonica history – from 1847 to C21st
● The day the harmonica got the blues – the birth of ‘Crossharp’
● How Chicago supercharged the harp – Valves, amps & distortion
● Meet the greats – Deford Bailey, Sonny Terry, Rice Miller & today’s beat box bluesers
● Can I play too? – How do I get started and what’s it gonna cost?

£6.00/£4.50 concessions, book your tickets here.

Room EW 1.10
posts.excerpt: It’s a child’s toy. It’s the only instrument through which you breathe. It has the power of a locomotive yet sleeps in your pocket and cries like a baby. Ben Hodgeson takes you on…

posts.title: Game Jam 2017: Playtesting session
posts.title_plain: Game Jam 2017: Playtesting session
posts.content:
The University of Portsmouth Game Jam, an annual, computer game-making competition, will be held from 12 to 16 June in the Eldon Building.

Over 100 participants have signed up to take part in this annual competition that brings together games students from the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries, as well as other departments and local FE colleges, and even staff and industry professionals too.

Teams will have a week to each make a game inspired by one or more of three randomly selected Wikipedia articles. Last year, the themes were Sickle-Cell Anaemia, Water Jousting, and Canadian Masterchef!

Take a look at a video of last year’s entries here.

Why not come along at 12.30pm on Friday 16 June to take part in the playtesting session and vote for your favourite game! The event will be held in Eldon Building South Wing, 1st Floor Multimedia Labs.

This year’s industry partners, who will be there to help with the judging, include Freejam and The Imaginarium, as well as several alumni who are working in indie games development.

The University was one of the first in the UK to run an educational Game Jam and, since it first began in 2008, this annual event has grown in popularity, year-on-year. Typically, these events are held over 24 to 48 hours but, to encourage sensible working hours and avoid the controversial practice of ‘crunch’, the University is holding this over five days, 9am to 5pm.As well as being a fun and creative experience, participating can help develop vital skills for future employment, including team working, communication, problem solving and social skills.

This year’s competition is being run by a team of games academics and support staff, including Neil Dansey, Senior Lecturer in Computer Games Technology and Clifford Phillips, Senior Technician.

To find out more about the Game Jam, please contact Neil or Clifford, visit gamejam.port.ac.uk, or watch the video.
posts.excerpt: The University of Portsmouth Game Jam, an annual, computer game-making competition, will be held from 12 to 16 June in the Eldon Building. Over 100 participants have signed up to take part in…

eventvenue: Eldon Building South Wing, 1st Floor Multimedia Labs

posts.title: Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries Graduate Show
posts.title_plain: Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries Graduate Show
posts.content:
The Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries is pleased to announce the date of this year’s Graduate Show, open to our friends across the University, industry and city partners, families and members of the public.

Eldon Building transforms into a series of showcasing spaces that display outstanding achievements by graduating students in architecture, art and design, creative technologies, and media and performing arts, before showcasing at major venues in London.

There will be opportunities to purchase quality student work and witness students entering the next stage of their careers. During the celebration evening, there will be exhibitions, live performances, film and animation screenings, and demonstrations of pioneering digital technologies.

This is a show not to be missed – everyone is welcome. Save the date in your diary now. There’s no need to book, just turn up and join the celebration!

Want to keep up to date with the latest information, or let us know that you’re coming? Check out the CCI Graduate Show 2017 on Facebook!

The Architecture and Art and Design show will continue the following week 5-9 June, 10am-4pm.

posts.title: Weekend Trip to Cornwall: The Eden Project and Newquay
posts.title_plain: Weekend Trip to Cornwall: The Eden Project and Newquay
posts.content:
Tickets only £85!

Celebrate the end of term and join us on our weekend trip to Cornwall!

Day 1: The Eden Project –  The Eden Project is a truly unique experience, in the heart of Cornwall. A dramatic global garden filled with jungles and waterfalls.

Day 2: Full day to spend in Newquay as you wish – go surfing, enjoy the beach, experience the beautiful Cornish countryside or take an excursion.

Day 3 – Half day in Newquay to spend as you wish, then coach travel back to Portsmouth.

Tickets include coach travel, tickets to the Eden Project, two nights accommodation in Newquay, including breakfast.

posts.title: Facebook Live Event: ‘How to create a successful crowdfunding campaign’
posts.title_plain: Facebook Live Event: ‘How to create a successful crowdfunding campaign’
posts.content:
The University’s Alumni Association is excited to announce the launch of our Facebook Live Series where alumni, students and staff are invited to tune in online and hear live panel discussions on crowdfunding, employability and entrepreneurship.

With four events planned throughout the year, you will hear real-life examples from alumni who are at various stages in their careers, in different industries. There is an opportunity to ask questions before and during each live event that will be put to the guest speakers.

The first event in the series – ‘How to create a successful crowdfunding campaign’ – is taking place on Thursday 25 May 2017, 1pm–1.30pm.

Streamed live from the Cell Block Studios, a creative workspace for businesses in the Historic Dockyard, Director of Undergraduate Programmes in Economics, Professor Joe Cox, will be discussing his top tips on how to successfully reach your crowdfunding goal.

Also on the panel, will be the founders of DICE, who successfully raised £11,662 for Portsmouth’s first board game café and, currently at the beginning stage of their crowdfunding campaign, Revolv, who are supporting emerging artists by organising talks and events. They will be giving valuable insight into what it’s like to create and manage a crowdfunding campaign and what fundamental lessons were learnt throughout the process.

Get involved

You can ask the panel questions during the live filming or alternatively submit your crowdfunding questions prior to the event by emailing the Alumni team on alumni@port.ac.uk.

Join the live discussion by visiting the Alumni Association’s Facebook event page. To be notified when this event goes live, please select ‘going’.

If you manage a Facebook account at the University, and feel your audience will benefit from joining the live session on Thursday, please share this event immediately after it has gone live at 1pm.
posts.excerpt: The University’s Alumni Association is excited to announce the launch of our Facebook Live Series where alumni, students and staff are invited to tune in online and hear live panel discussions on crowdfunding,…

posts.title: Fifth edition, Unifest 2017: opening ceremony
posts.title_plain: Fifth edition, Unifest 2017: opening ceremony
posts.content:
The School of Media and Performing Arts invites you to the opening of ‘Fifth Edition, Unifest 2017’, a festival taking place at the University from 22 May to 1 June.

The festivities will begin in the foyer of the White Swan Building at 1pm on Monday 22 May and the opening ceremony will include performances from The Lark (Band), UOP Tap That, Marybeth Anches and James West and The Skit Sisters.

The festival includes performances such as Surrounded (Wednesday, 24 May, 12pm) When Everyone Talks at Once (Friday, 26 May, 3pm) and The Reunion (Thursday, 1 June).

You can find all the details on our social media: Facebook: @SMPAunifest, Twitter: @SMPAunifest and Instagram: @SMPAunifest_ with the hashtag #UNIFEST2017.

posts.title: Developing Mindfulness
posts.title_plain: Developing Mindfulness
posts.content:
Mindfulness is the art of directing your attention in a kindly and non-judgemental way. Studies have shown that it can be very helpful if you are prone to worrying about the future or find it hard to let go of situations or events once they have passed. In mindfulness we try to keep our mind on the present.

The aim of the programme is to introduce you to the skill of mindfulness. It is a skill that requires practice, so we meet together to do some gentle exercises and our discussion is confined to information about those practices. You will be asked to do a daily five-minute practice of mindfulness of the breath and you will be encouraged to develop your awareness of the theme of each session in your own time during the week following.

The rolling programme consists of six sessions, focusing on a different theme each week and repeating throughout term-time from January to May (no sessions in Easter break), so you can join at anytime. Once you have completed six sessions, you’ll have the opportunity to stay on and repeat them should you wish to (providing there are spaces). This may help you to maintain a mindfulness practice.

To enrol on this course you will first need to meet briefly with a Wellbeing Service practitioner (arranged when booking).

Every Tuesday during term-time until May 16.

For more information or to book a place on this course:

E: wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk
T: 023 9284 3466
or call in to the Nuffield Reception

Click here for information about other Student Wellbeing courses and workshops.
posts.excerpt: Mindfulness is the art of directing your attention in a kindly and non-judgemental way. Studies have shown that it can be very helpful if you are prone to worrying about the future or…

posts.title: CCI Faculty Bumper Book Launch!
posts.title_plain: CCI Faculty Bumper Book Launch!
posts.content:
Blackwells in Portsmouth will host a launch event for multiple books from the School of Media and Performing Arts next month, with guest Olly Gruner of the School of Art and Design.

The books are:

  • Dr Rebecca Janicker – Reading American Horror Story: Essays on the Television Franchise April 2017 McFarland & Co, includes an essay by Dr Emma Austin
  • Dr Oliver Gruner – Screening the Sixties: Hollywood Cinema and the Politics of Memory (Palgrave Macmillan, 2016) (Available here.)
  • Dr Stephen Harper Screening Bosnia: Geopolitics, Gender and Nationalism in Film and TV Images of the 1992-95 War (Bloomsbury, March 9th)
  • Dr Steven O’Brien And Joe Machine – Britannic Myths
  • Dr Laura MacDonald and William Everett – The Palgrave Handbook of Musical Theatre Producers (Available here.)
  • Dr Deborah Shaw – Latin American Women Filmmakers: Production, Politics, Poetics, co-edited with Deborah Martin for the World Cinema Series at I.B.Tauris
  • Prof Justin Smith (with a chapter by Dr Laurie Ede) – Routledge Companion to British Cinema History – coedited with I.Q. Hunter and Laraine Porter

The launch will be introduced by Professor Trevor Keeble, the new Dean of the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries.
posts.excerpt: Blackwells in Portsmouth will host a launch event for multiple books from the School of Media and Performing Arts next month, with guest Olly Gruner of the School of Art and Design. The…

posts.title: The Story of You & I (A Trilogy) – A Performance by Vertical Exchange Performance Collective, (VEX)
posts.title_plain: The Story of You & I (A Trilogy) – A Performance by Vertical Exchange Performance Collective, (VEX)
posts.content:
The Story of You & I has been created by Dr Joanna Bucknall in the School of Media and Performing Arts.  Let us unburden you, well at least let us try! ‘The Story of You & I‘ is an intimate, interactive experience that explores the themes of love, loss and regret in three parts.

You can experience different episodes of the trilogy across three afternoons, or each evening you can come and binge on them all in one sitting. Come join us, listen, and together we can devour it, we can hold it, we will let it go.

TSOY&I will premier in the Brighton Fringe Festival 2017, between 5-7 and 24-26 May 2017 at ETEN + DRINKEN.

Book your tickets here!

See the trailer on YouTube.

About VEX

Joanna and Nigel are co-artistic directors of Vertical Exchange Performance Collective (VEX) and were founded in 2005. We employ live art, duration, immersive and on-on-one strategies to provoke, challenge and engage audiences. VEX make work that aims to explore the contemporary experience and all the intricate moments that our lives present. Our aim is to produce performance work that involves its audiences at a fundamental level. By employing experimental and compelling performance devices we offer audiences a truly participative experience. Our works seek to explode the liminal space and engage audiences in liminoid acts. We make performance work that engages audience in the reflection of self and identity in innovative and interactive ways. We are interested in creating a new and original live art performance event that presents an immersive environment in which the audience can participate with agency and efficacy. We are a live art collective and are interested in the way in which performance can be employed to reframe the everyday and the mundane to generate new perspectives on our contemporary experience. We use the poetics of everyday action, tasks rules and games to create our performance work. Life is our found material and people are our resource.Joanna is an associate artist at the New Theatre Royal, (NTR) in Portsmouth. Previously we have worked with venues such as The Barbican in Plymouth, Camden People’s Theatre, The Basement in Brighton, Performing Arts Centre Lincoln and Battersea Arts Centre. We have also been involved in various programmes with the Live Art Development Agency and Fierce.

Find VEX on Facebook, on Twitter: @playwithmeart, or follow them on YouTube!

posts.title: A Survival Guide to Panic
posts.title_plain: A Survival Guide to Panic
posts.content:
This workshop is designed to take some of the fear out of panic attacks. By understanding what panic attacks are and why we have them, we can start to understand how to cope with them better.

Participants will learn the science of panic attacks, why it is they keep on happening and what can be done to help.

To enrol for this workshop it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

E: wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk
T: 023 9284 3466
or call in to the Nuffield Reception

Click here for information about other Student Wellbeing courses and workshops.
